channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: An electric race car has lapped Daytona for the first time
item.description: We may well see an electric touring car series in the US in the next few years.

item.title: A curious observer’s guide to quantum mechanics, pt. 4: Looking at the stars
item.description: How do photons travel across light years? (Their quantum waviness enables modern telescopes.)

item.title: New study: A zero-emissions US is now pretty cheap
item.description: In 2050, benefits to the US offset costs, but there are some unexpected outcomes.

item.title: Why kids matter in the quest to stamp out COVID-19
item.description: Inoculating kids can help protect an entire population.

item.title: Google Play bans open source Matrix client Element, citing “abusive content” [Updated]
item.description: Banning a Matrix client for content is really no different from banning a Web browser.

item.title: A new $110 light gun for old Duck Hunts: Ars tests an HDTV-friendly option
item.description: It’s far from “plug-and-play,” but awesome for devoted retro gamers.

item.title: Lawmakers take aim at insidious digital “dark patterns”
item.description: New laws bar efforts to trick consumers into handing over data or money.

item.title: Nine Russian adventurers mysteriously froze to death—a new theory explains why
item.description: 60 years later, new evidence points to a peculiar kind of avalanche as the culprit.

item.title: What’s really going on with Elon Musk, the FAA, and Starship?
item.description: In the end, it’s likely that cooler heads will prevail.

item.title: It’s the wombat’s strange intestines, not its anus, that produces cubed poo
item.description: “Our research finally proves that you really can fit a square peg through a round hole.”

item.title: Cable ISP warns “excessive” uploaders, says network can’t handle heavy usage
item.description: Mediacom says heavy uploaders harm network even if they don’t exceed data cap.

item.title: No, WallStreetBets isn’t robbing Wall Street to help the little guy
item.description: Analysis: A seductive “short squeeze” narrative obscures what’s really happening.

item.title: 30% of “SolarWinds hack” victims didn’t actually use SolarWinds
item.description: “This campaign should not be thought of as the SolarWinds campaign,” says DHS.

item.title: Robinhood’s plan to “democratize finance” hit a GameStop-shaped speed bump [Updated]
item.description: Liquidity requirements lead to unexpected restraints, and it’s probably legal.

item.title: COVID variants throw J&J vaccine a curveball, lowering efficacy to 66%
item.description: The adenovirus vector-based vaccine is another useful tool against SARS-CoV-2.

item.title: YouTube’s new “Clips” feature lets users share 60-second clips of videos
item.description: Just like on Twitch, “clips” lets users chop up and share sections of videos.

item.title: 25 years later, Midway’s lost “MLB Jam” arcade game has been found
item.description: Includes oral history of unreleased Power-Up Baseball: Cool trackballs, bad business.

item.title: Today’s best tech deals: Apple’s M1 Mac Mini, Xbox controllers, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has discounts on noise-cancelling headphones and gaming mice.

item.title: Rocket Report: FAA grounds Starship, Biden’s big rocket dilemma
item.description: “The launch vehicle shall deliver a minimum 6,065 kg Europa Clipper spacecraft.”

item.title: WallStreetBets craze pushes dogecoin up 5x in 24 hours
item.description: The social media mob that pumped up GameStop is now dabbling in cryptocurrency.

item.title: Coronavirus variants: What they do and how worried you should be
item.description: The Ars guide to the coronavirus variants

item.title: Every crazy thing that happened in Apple and Facebook’s privacy feud today
item.description: Apple CEO Tim Cook claims Facebook’s model leads to polarization and violence.

item.title: New Biden executive order makes science, evidence central to policy
item.description: Agencies will perform evidence-based evaluations of their own performance.

item.title: Rocky Linux gets a new sponsor—Gregory Kurtzer’s startup, Ctrl IQ
item.description: Money can’t buy you love—but it can sponsor a new Linux distro.

item.title: GM says no more tailpipe emissions by 2035, carbon neutrality by 2040
item.description: GM says that 40 percent of US models will be battery electric vehicles by 2025.

item.title: Intel’s first discrete GPU in 20+ years is only for OEMs, integrators
item.description: The DG1 only works in special motherboards—no support for the enthusiast market.

item.title: Biden’s approach to climate: Calling it a crisis and treating it that way
item.description: From diplomacy to infrastructure, a deep re-evaluation of the role of government.

item.title: That’s a wrap—No Starship launch attempt on Thursday afternoon [Updated]
item.description: It has only been about six weeks since SN8 flew.

item.title: State reps try to ban Comcast data cap and price hikes until pandemic is over
item.description: Massachusetts bill would halt data caps, price hikes, new fees, and ISP shutoffs.

item.title: Facebook “Supreme Court” overrules company in 4 of its first 5 decisions
item.description: Rulings deal with everything from bare breasts to the war in Azerbaijan.

item.title: GoT alums among announced cast for Netflix Sandman adaptation
item.description: Gwendoline Christie and Charles Dance join Tom Sturridge as Morpheus.

item.title: From first to sixth: Huawei’s phone business tanks thanks to US sanctions
item.description: Huawei was the #1 phone vendor earlier this year, but the export ban is killing it.

item.title: Samsung says auto chip shortage could hit smartphones
item.description: Warning comes as car companies lobby governments for help.

item.title: Discord bans WallStreetBets as subreddit briefly goes private [Updated]
item.description: Robinhood app restricts stock purchasing as regulators express worry.

item.title: Tesla Model S to get comprehensive refresh, 200mph “Plaid” version
item.description: There are new batteries and motors, and a yoke instead of a steering wheel.

item.title: Apple reports double-digit sales booms for every product category in Q1 2021
item.description: There are now more than one billion iPhones in the wild.

item.title: Tesla reports its first annual profit
item.description: Tesla made a $721 million profit thanks to $1.58 billion in regulatory credits.

item.title: Sidewalk-robot startup celebrates 1 million deliveries
item.description: Low speeds enabled Starship to launch its service safely and quickly.

item.title: Unstable helium adds a limit on the ongoing saga of the proton’s size
item.description: Putting a muon in orbit around a helium nucleus gives us measurements that make sense.

item.title: “Warp speed,” “Prime Directive” predate Star Trek, per new reference tool
item.description: Historical Dictionary of Science Fiction is a new, and free, online reference tool.

item.title: Microsoft earnings: Xbox hardware sales shot up 86% with Series X/S
item.description: As usual, Microsoft’s cloud business helped drive revenue to new highs.

item.title: Samsung’s reportedly ready to supply foldable displays to rival companies
item.description: Samsung’s foldable panel exclusivity is ending, with Chinese phones due in 2H 2021.

item.title: The complete moron’s guide to GameStop’s stock roller coaster
item.description: How does this epic rally end? And can it be repeated?

item.title: AT&T eats a $15.5 billion impairment charge as DirecTV debacle continues
item.description: AT�T lost 617,000 Premium TV customers in Q4 and 3 million in the calendar year.

item.title: 84% of Mexican hand sanitizers toxic or flawed; FDA issues drastic alert
item.description: The regulatory agency has issued alerts for over 200 products.

item.title: Vehicle recalls cluster because OEMs wait for rivals to move first
item.description: Fears of falling stock prices may be responsible for the phenomenon.

item.title: The Trump administration left Biden with a rocket dilemma
item.description: “NASA needs to go back and look at what the options are to go to the Moon.”

item.title: Chromecast, Fire TV Stick, or Roku: What’s the best streaming stick for ~$50?
item.description: We pit the three premier $50 streaming sticks head-to-head to see which is best.

item.title: Basic pandemic safety limits spread in schools
item.description: Infections spread in a school system were far lower than in its surrounding towns.

item.title: Warrior princess fights to save humanity in Raya and the Last Dragon trailer
item.description: “I wish to join this fellowship of butt-kickery.”

item.title: Plex adds game-streaming as paid add-on, completely botches the landing
item.description: $4.99/mo service needs to straighten many issues before meriting the cost.

item.title: Sony adds HDMI to last year’s Android phone, charges $2,500
item.description: It’s not a foldable. It’s not plated in gold. It just has an HDMI port.

item.title: SpaceX adds laser links to Starlink satellites to serve Earth’s polar areas
item.description: Laser links connect Starlink satellites, reducing need for ground stations.

item.title: iOS 14.4 and iPadOS 14.4 hit supported devices today
item.description: Apple also released tvOS 14.4 and watchOS 7.3.

item.title: Sony’s best noise-cancelling headphones are down to their lowest price today
item.description: Dealmaster also has discounts on LG OLED TVs, Apple’s M1 Mac Mini, and more.

item.title: Google Play bans video app for standard “.ass” subtitle support
item.description: “Advanced Sub Station alpha” files, or a naughty word for a butt? Who knows!

item.title: Apple’s long-time hardware lead steps down to work on mysterious “new project”
item.description: It’s unusual for the leader of department to shift focus to just one product.
